name: Vedic Dharmic Framework
description: Argumentation framework derived from Vedic philosophy, Nyaya epistemology, and dharmic ethics. Applicable to governance decisions where duty, context, and emergency override intersect.

principles.name: Swadharma (Personal Duty)
principles.description: Each role carries specific obligations. A CISO's swadharma is to protect systems and make security decisions. Acting outside one's competence violates swadharma.
principles.argument_generation: When a decision falls within the decision-maker's designated role, generate a supporting argument. When it exceeds their role, generate a cautionary argument.

principles.name: Kuladharma (Organizational Duty)
principles.description: Obligations to one's organization and team. Decisions must consider institutional continuity and the welfare of colleagues.
principles.argument_generation: Generate arguments weighing organizational impact of each decision option.

principles.name: Rashtradharma (Societal Duty)
principles.description: Obligations to the broader society. Security decisions in critical infrastructure carry societal weight beyond the organization.
principles.argument_generation: For scenarios affecting public safety or national security, generate high-strength societal duty arguments.

principles.name: Sanatana Dharma (Universal Ethics)
principles.description: Foundational ethical principles: non-harm (ahimsa), truthfulness (satya), non-stealing (asteya). These override lower-level duties when in conflict.
principles.argument_generation: Generate arguments from universal ethical principles. These attack lower-level duty arguments when they conflict with fundamental ethics.

principles.name: Apad-Dharma (Emergency Ethics)
principles.description: In extraordinary circumstances (apad), normal rules may be suspended. The Mahabharata recognizes that survival-level crises demand ethical flexibility â€” but the deviation must be proportional, temporary, and justified.
principles.argument_generation: When scenario difficulty is 'extraordinary' and time pressure is extreme, generate apad-dharma arguments that attack rigid rule-following. These arguments must include proportionality constraints.

principles.name: Pratyaksha (Direct Perception)
principles.description: Nyaya epistemology holds that direct perception is the primary means of valid knowledge. In governance, this means first-hand evidence and direct observation outweigh inference and testimony.
principles.argument_generation: Arguments based on direct evidence (sensor data, logs, forensic findings) receive strength bonus. Arguments based purely on inference receive a penalty.

principles.name: Anumana (Inference)
principles.description: Valid inference from known premises. In governance, this covers risk models, probabilistic assessments, and AI confidence scores. Anumana is valid but subordinate to pratyaksha.
principles.argument_generation: Arguments based on AI inference, statistical models, or probabilistic reasoning. Valid but attackable by direct evidence arguments.

principles.name: Shabda (Authoritative Testimony)
principles.description: Knowledge from trustworthy sources. In governance, this covers policy documents, regulatory requirements, and expert consultation.
principles.argument_generation: Arguments based on authoritative sources (regulations, expert consultation, established policy). Strength varies by source reliability.

attack_rules.rule: universal_dharma attacks lower duties when they conflict
attack_rules.condition: When following a lower duty would violate ahimsa, satya, or asteya

attack_rules.rule: apad_dharma attacks all duties in extraordinary circumstances
attack_rules.condition: When scenario difficulty is 'extraordinary' and time_pressure is extreme

attack_rules.rule: pratyaksha attacks anumana when they conflict
attack_rules.condition: When direct evidence contradicts inferential reasoning

attack_rules.rule: rashtradharma attacks kuladharma in public safety scenarios
attack_rules.condition: When organizational interests conflict with public safety

academic_references: Ganeri, J. (2001). Philosophy in Classical India.
Matilal, B.K. (1998). The Character of Logic in India.
